text:
THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES

FRIDAY, JUNE 16, 1888

SUNDAY CHURCH SERVICES

St. Alban's Church, Services 11 a.m., Rev. Mr. Wright, preacher.

St. Paul's Church, 2 p.m., Rev. Canon Foster, preacher.

St. James' Church, 3 p.m., Rev. J. Taylor, preacher.

ST. ALBAN'S PARISH

Rev. Mr. Wright, Rector.

Rev. Mr. Lawrence, Assistant.

Rev. Mr. Davison, Assistant.

Rev. Mr. Jackson, Assistant.

Rev. Mr. Howard, Assistant.

PRAYER MEETING

Wednesday evening at St. Alban's Church.

Rev. Mr. Howard, pastor in charge.

FRIDAY, JUNE 8, 1888

THE N.W. ASSEMBLY.

As nomination day approaches, there appears naturally to be considerable interest manifested in the coming election for the N.W. Assembly. We are interested particularly in the division of Prince Albert, Kinistino and Batoche, but with the exception of Prince Albert—which has to elect two members—it does not appear that sufficient interest is being shown to be in the field. In this division (P.A.) it has been settled for some time that Messrs. O. E. Hughes and J. F. Bett will be candidates, and as we fully approve of the candidacy of both these gentlemen, we announce our determination to give them our support. We care not whether they are brought out by one party or the other as independents. They both good men, and we do not think that there are better likely to offer themselves as candidates. Mr. Hughes has already been tried; he has been our representative in the Legislative Council for three years, and as such has given complete satisfaction. We have never in all that time heard a single complaint against him; even those who are politically opposed to Mr. Hughes have always been satisfied with his past record, and we believe no opposition would be offered were he in the field alone. We consider that it would be very unwise at this time to reject Mr. Hughes because he stands apart from his many other qualifications; he has had three years experience as a legislator, and will be able to turn that experience to good account; while Mr. Bett, though an inexperienced man, a considerable time to get hold of the ropes and make their influence felt, Mr. Hughes will go there well known and familiar with the work devolving upon him as a representative. We therefore urge Mr. Bett because we have every confidence in his ability and integrity. He has been in Prince Albert ten years, and has contributed largely towards making the place what it is; he has been a member of council, a business man and has ever been a strong advocate of the interests of our district and people, and on all questions affecting the public welfare he has always been in the right place, and from our knowledge of Mr. Bett, we feel confident that when elected—as he will be—he will neglect the interests of his constituents and will prove to be one of the most useful men in the Assembly. It may be objected that because the Conservative party have not nominated any candidates in this division, that they are Conservative and running on Dominion party lines. It may be unfortunate that party politics should be allowed to enter into anything. Of that point we do not feel called upon to express an opinion. In Kinistino, we believe, Capt. Horsley is meeting with success. We do not know who is to oppose him, and we would be sorry to see any opposition. In Batoche we understand, soliciting the suffrages of the people, not as a party man, but on his own merits, and we think the electors of that division could not possibly make a worse choice than to give to the man what they always wanted, a farmer representing farmers, and they will have more, they will have a man of good ability, sound judgment and integrity and a man of commendable experience, and who will carry a great deal of weight in the Assembly.

We are pleased to note the arrival in Town last week of Mr. Hartly Gibbon, Superintendent of Great Western Telegraph Lines in the North West. Mr. Gibbon was here last year and is very surprised at the improvements and growth of the Town in the meantime. He very much approves of the place and the citizens of Prince Albert and promises to make frequent visits to the Town. We are sure that the citizens of Prince Albert will extend a cordial welcome to him at any time and would be very much pleased to see him again. We understand, Mr. Gibbon's headquarters have been for a long time at Battleford, to which place he has returned. He is at present making arrangements for the opening of the Telegraph office at Dark Lake which he hopes will be opened shortly, and will be an added attraction to the lines in the North West.

Glovers or a Big Bone.—When Mr. Gibbon's Handbook first published in our volume, it was a comparatively small book. Some years after, an addition was made of nearly 5,000 pictorial illustrations. A table of contents appeared in an Appendix of new words that had come into use. A year or two later came an entirely new revised edition of larger size, with 3,000 Pictorial Illustrations, then another renewal of the new year, a third edition, containing 4,000 Illustrations, and a Supplement of nearly 5,000 New Words were added, and now there is a fourth edition, containing a Supplement of a Gazetteer of the World, of over 25,000 Titles. The work is now not only the largest dictionary in Canada, but also the largest pictorial Dictionary, a Gazetteer of the World, and a great many other good things in its many valuable Tables.

PROCLAMATION.

CANADA.

Northwest Territories.

Electoral District of KINSTINO

Public Notice is hereby given to the Electors of the Electoral District of Kinstino, that in consequence of a writ issued, and to be addressed by order of His Excellency the Governor General, bearing date the fourth day of June, 1888, calling for the return of the said District.

THE SCHOOL HOUSE

KINSTINO.

SATURDAY, THE 23RD JUNE, 1888

from noon until two of the clock in the afternoon, for the purpose of the purpose of nominating ten persons to represent them in the Legislative Assembly of the Northwest Territories, and in case a Poll become necessary, such persons shall be elected by ballot at the time prescribed by law at the polling places appointed by the Returning Officer, as shall, after the nomination, be appointed by the Returning Officer.

Of which all persons are hereby respectfully invited to take notice, and govern themselves accordingly.

Given under my hand at Kinstino in the Northwest Territories, this twelfth day of June, 1888.

T. N. CAMPBELL,
Returning Officer.

TOWN COUNCIL

The Town Council held a regular meeting on Monday evening last. His Worship Mayor W. H. Chesnutt presiding.

Mr. J. T. R. A. inspired by the late Mr. James Jackson for the position of Town Clerk.

A motion was made by Mr. R. E. W. Wilson, 21, Elm Street, N., that Mr. Hobson be appointed Town Clerk in place of Mr. James Jackson; also a motion by Mr. P. W. Wall for the re-election of the late Mr. W. H. Chesnutt as Town Clerk.

The Board of Works presented a very carefully prepared report, containing full account of the erection cost, which amounted to $5,000.

The following accounts were ordered to be paid before May 31st, viz.: Henry Teague, $57; Mrs. Eliza Smith, $51; Mrs. Mary Williams, $47; Mrs. Emma Davis, $42; Mrs. Sarah Ray, $39; Mrs. Mary Smith, $36; Mrs. Mary Williams, $35; Mrs. Mary Lisa, $32; Mrs. Sarah Ray, $29; Mrs. Mary Smith, $28; Mrs. Mary Lisa, $25; Mrs. Sarah Ray, $24; Mrs. Mary Smith, $23.

A letter from Mr. Robert M'Ghim reading, "I have the honour to apply successfully for the office of Town Surveyor," signed by Mr. Robert M'Ghim.

The Council then adjourned.
